Fine-Tuning Personalization in Federated Learning
to Mitigate Adversarial Clients

Youssef Allouah Abdellah El Mrini Rachid Guerraoui Nirupam Gupta Authors are listed in alphabetical order.Correspondence to : Abdellah El Mrini <abdellah.elmrini@epfl.ch>. â€ƒâ€ƒ Rafael Pinot
Ecole Polytechnique FÃ©dÃ©rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Switzerland
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is an appealing paradigm that allows a group of machines (a.k.a. clients) to learn collectively while keeping their data local. However, due to the heterogeneity between the clientsâ€™ data distributions, the model obtained through the use of FL algorithms may perform poorly on some clientâ€™s data. Personalization addresses this issue by enabling each client to have a different model tailored to their own data while simultaneously benefiting from the other clientsâ€™ data. We consider an FL setting where some clients can be adversarial, and we derive conditions under which full collaboration fails. Specifically, we analyze the generalization performance of an interpolated personalized FL framework in the presence of adversarial clients, and we precisely characterize situations when full collaboration performs strictly worse than fine-tuned personalization. Our analysis determines how much we should scale down the level of collaboration, according to data heterogeneity and the tolerable fraction of adversarial clients. We support our findings with empirical results on mean estimation and binary classification problems, considering synthetic and benchmark image classification datasets.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is the de facto standard for a group of machines (also referred to as clients) to learn a common model on their collective dataÂ (Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2021). The benefit of this method is twofold: the clients (1) retain control over their local data (as they do not communicate them to a central server) and (2) share the computational workload during the learning procedure. Although FL is a promising learning paradigm, it also comes with its own technical challenges, the first of which is data heterogeneity. Indeed, each client holds only a portion of the common dataset, which is not necessarily a faithful representation of the entire population. This could lead to disagreements amongst clients on model updates, rendering the task of learning an accurate model in this context cumbersome. Nevertheless, when all machines correctly follow a prescribed algorithm, this problem can be solved using either a distributed implementation of the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm or variants of the federated averaging schemeÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017; Khaled etÂ al.,, 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2020). Another negative impact of data heterogeneity is the non-uniformity of model accuracy. Specifically, while an FL algorithm outputs a model that is accurate on average, the accuracy of this model on different clientsâ€™ local data could vary significantly.

Personalization. Personalized FL attempts to address the aforementioned shortcoming on non-uniform model accuracy by having clients collaborate to design individual models that generalize well over their local data distributionsÂ (Vanhaesebrouck etÂ al.,, 2017; Sattler etÂ al.,, 2020; Fallah etÂ al.,, 2020; Hanzely etÂ al.,, 2020). This approach is highly relevant to many modern machine learning applications, as it tailors the training of each model to the needs of the respective client. To get a more precise view of this approach, consider a general supervised learning task with ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} denoting the input space and ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y} the output space. Personalized FL involves nğ‘›n clients which can communicate, through a central trusted machine (a.k.a. the server). This optimization problem can be solved in several ways, and we have at out disposal a rich literature on personalized FL schemesÂ (Mansour etÂ al.,, 2020; Fallah etÂ al.,, 2020; Marfoq etÂ al.,, 2021). We focus on a specific personalization scheme wherein each client aims to solve for the Î»ğœ†\lambda-interpolated empirical loss minimization problem:

minÎ¸iâˆˆÎ˜â¡â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸i)â‰”(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹â„’iâ€‹(Î¸i)+Î»â€‹â„’â€‹(Î¸i),â‰”subscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–Î˜superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğœƒğ‘–1ğœ†subscriptâ„’ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğœ†â„’subscriptğœƒğ‘–\min_{\theta_{i}\in\Theta}\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta_{i})\coloneqq(1-\lambda)\mathcal{L}_{i}(\theta_{i})+\lambda\mathcal{L}(\theta_{i}), (2)

where â„’â€‹(Î¸)â‰”1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ„’iâ€‹(Î¸),âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜formulae-sequenceâ‰”â„’ğœƒ1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœƒfor-allğœƒÎ˜\mathcal{L}{(\theta)}\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{L}_{i}{(\theta)},~{}\forall\theta\in\Theta, and Î»âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ†01\lambda\in[0,1]. When Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1, the problem reduces to the standard FL objective and corresponds to a full collaboration amongst the clients. The case of Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 represents the absence of collaboration, i.e., each client minimizes its local empirical loss. We use the terminology fine-tuned personalization to refer to the objective of solving forÂ (2) when Î»âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ†01\lambda\in(0,1) is determined by optimizing the learning performance in retrospect.

Robustness. Standard personalized FL approaches usually assume that all clients correctly follow a prescribed protocol, and hence do not consider the possibility of adversarial clients. Robustness to such clients, a.k.aÂ â€œByzantine robustnessâ€, refers to the design of FL schemes that yield accurate models even when some clients arbitrarily deviate from the algorithm and can send potentially corrupted information to other clients: This could result from poisonous data or code, or attacks from malicious players. Although Byzantine robustness has received significant attention in the FL communityÂ (Guerraoui etÂ al.,, 2024), it remains largely understudied in the context of personalized FL. In fact, prior work has shown that the presence of adversarial clients induces a fundamental optimization error that grows with the heterogeneity across clientsâ€™ local dataÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2022; Allouah etÂ al.,, 2024). This optimization error is at odds with the improvement in generalization, which is offered by collaborating with other correct clients, to a point where collaboration is rendered vacuous. The main motivation for our work is to quantify the impact of adversarial clients on the relevance of collaboration for any correct client.

1.1 Problem Setting

Given the set of nğ‘›n clients, we aim to tolerate the presence of at most f<n/2ğ‘“ğ‘›2f<n/2 adversarial clients. Such clients can respond arbitrarily to the queries made by the server, e.g., a gradient computation on their local dataset. We also call these clients Byzantine adversaries. The identity of Byzantine adversaries is a priori unknown to the correct (i.e., non-adversarial) clients, otherwise, the problem is rendered trivial. As we explain above, when no client is adversarial, the objective of each client iğ‘–i is to minimize its own risk, defined inÂ (1), by solving for the interpolated empirical loss minimization problemÂ (2). However, in the presence of adversarial clients, a correct client cannot simply seek a solution toÂ (2), as they can never have truthful access to the information about Byzantine adversariesâ€™ datasets. A more reasonable goal is to minimize an interpolation between their local and the correct clientsâ€™ average loss functions. We formally define the robust-interpolated objective for client iğ‘–i as follows:

minÎ¸iâˆˆÎ˜â¡â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸i)â‰”(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹â„’iâ€‹(Î¸i)+Î»â€‹â„’ğ’â€‹(Î¸i),â‰”subscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–Î˜superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğœƒğ‘–1ğœ†subscriptâ„’ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğœ†subscriptâ„’ğ’subscriptğœƒğ‘–\min_{\theta_{i}\in\Theta}\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta_{i})\coloneqq(1-\lambda)\mathcal{L}_{i}(\theta_{i})+\lambda\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{C}}(\theta_{i}), (3)

where ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} represents the set of correct clients, â„’ğ’â€‹(Î¸)â‰”1|ğ’|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’â„’iâ€‹(Î¸),âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptâ„’ğ’ğœƒ1ğ’subscriptğ‘–ğ’subscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœƒfor-allğœƒÎ˜\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{C}}{(\theta)}\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{\left\lvert{\mathcal{C}}\right\rvert}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}\mathcal{L}_{i}{(\theta)},~{}\forall\theta\in\Theta, and Î»âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ†01\lambda\in[0,1] is called the collaboration level. Similar toÂ (2), Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 and Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1, respectively, reduce to local learning which can be solved with local SGDÂ (Stich,, 2018), and Byzantine-robust FL which can be tackled using a robust variant of distributed gradient descentÂ (Allouah etÂ al.,, 2023). Recall that ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} is a priori unknown to the correct clients, hence they can neither have access to â„’ğ’subscriptâ„’ğ’\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{C}} nor to its gradients. A correct client can only approximate any information on â„’ğ’subscriptâ„’ğ’\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{C}}, where the approximation error grows with both f/nğ‘“ğ‘›f/n and data heterogeneity, shown inÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2022; Allouah etÂ al.,, 2024).

1.2 Contributions

We establish optimization and generalization guarantees on the interpolated personalized objectiveÂ (3) in the presence of adversarial clients, and show how the degree of collaboration Î»ğœ†\lambda, asymptotically navigates the trade-off between the fundamental optimization error due to adversarial clients and the improved generalization performance thanks to the collaboration with correct ones.

This sheds light on specific situations in which full collaboration performs strictly worse than fine-tuned personalization, and even sometimes worse than local learning. Precisely, we extend an important result from domain adaptation (Ben-David etÂ al.,, 2010), showing that data from a distinct distribution cannot be beneficial for the local learning task when the heterogeneity is above a certain threshold, which depends on the local sample size and the hypothesis class complexity. In the context of Byzantine robust distributed learning, we show that even if data heterogeneity is low enough, the level of collaboration should be rescaled by a parameter that both depends on the fraction of adversaries and the gradient dissimilarity between correct clients. Essentially, while the effect of collaboration could be captured by substraction between the local task complexity and the heterogeneity of local distributions in a Byzantine-free context, we show that it is further captured by a multiplicative factor in the presence of adversaries. The higher the dissimilarity between correct gradients (and the number of adversarial clients in the system), the smaller Î»ğœ†\lambda should be taken.

Our results show that for personalized FL, in most realistic contexts where heterogeneity between clients is not negligible, full collaboration is not optimal in the presence of adversarial clients. Moreover, the presence of these adversarial clients considerably limits the level of collaboration that could be useful for the correct clients, to the point where it is often more efficient to learn locally if the local task is sufficiently simple.

1.3 Paper Outline

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ 2presents the mean estimation setting as a warm-up and special case of the framework presented in SectionÂ 1.1. The goal is to give an intuition on settings in which personalization can or cannot help reduce the estimation error in the presence of adversarial clients. SectionÂ 3 presents our analysis in the general binary classification setting, where we quantify the tension between the optimization error and the generalization gap in the presence of Byzantine adversaries. We also empirically validate our theory on the MNIST dataset. We defer full proofs to AppendixÂ C and our full experimental setup to AppendixÂ D. We also include further information on related work in AppendixÂ A.

Tightness of the bound.

While the right-hand side of PropositionÂ 1 may not be tight in general, we note that it is tight for Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 and Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1, in the homogeneous setting (Î”=0Î”0\Delta=0), provided that we use robust averaging with Îºâˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(f/n)ğœ…ğ’ªğ‘“ğ‘›\kappa\in\mathcal{O}(f/n). Interpretation.

Note that, in the above, the terms that represent the hardness of the local mean estimation task and the heterogeneity among correct clients are Ïƒ2msuperscriptğœ2ğ‘š\frac{\sigma^{2}}{m}, and â€–Î¼iâˆ’Î¼Â¯ğ’â€–2+Îºâ€‹Î”2superscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğœ‡ğ’2ğœ…superscriptÎ”2\|\mu_{i}-\overline{\mu}_{\mathcal{C}}\|^{2}+\kappa\Delta^{2} respectively. Indeed Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is the variance of each distribution, hence the local mean estimation task is essentially as hard as Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is large with respect to the number of points mğ‘šm each client has access to. Similarly, Î”2superscriptÎ”2\Delta^{2} essentially computes how far apart the true means of the correct clients are on average, and â€–Î¼iâˆ’Î¼Â¯ğ’â€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğœ‡ğ’2\|\mu_{i}-\overline{\mu}_{\mathcal{C}}\|^{2} penalizes especially the distance to the average of the correct clients for the one we observe (i.e., iâˆˆğ’ğ‘–ğ’i\in\mathcal{C}). By minimizing the right-hand side of PropositionÂ 1, we get

Î»âˆ—=(1âˆ’1nâˆ’f)â€‹Ïƒ2m(Îº+1)â€‹(1âˆ’1nâˆ’f)â€‹Ïƒ2m+â€–Î¼iâˆ’Î¼Â¯ğ’â€–2+Îºâ€‹Î”2,superscriptğœ†11ğ‘›ğ‘“superscriptğœ2ğ‘šğœ…111ğ‘›ğ‘“superscriptğœ2ğ‘šsuperscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğœ‡ğ’2ğœ…superscriptÎ”2\lambda^{*}=\frac{\left(1-\frac{1}{n-f}\right)\frac{\sigma^{2}}{m}}{(\kappa+1)\left(1-\frac{1}{n-f}\right)\frac{\sigma^{2}}{m}+\|\mu_{i}-\overline{\mu}_{\mathcal{C}}\|^{2}+\kappa\Delta^{2}}, (6)

which approaches 00 as â€–Î¼iâˆ’Î¼Â¯ğ’â€–2+Îºâ€‹Î”2superscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğœ‡ğ’2ğœ…superscriptÎ”2\|\mu_{i}-\overline{\mu}_{\mathcal{C}}\|^{2}+\kappa\Delta^{2} grows and 1/(1+Îº)11ğœ…1/(1+\kappa) when â€–Î¼iâˆ’Î¼Â¯ğ’â€–2+Îºâ€‹Î”2â‰ªÏƒ2/mmuch-less-thansuperscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğœ‡ğ’2ğœ…superscriptÎ”2superscriptğœ2ğ‘š\|\mu_{i}-\overline{\mu}_{\mathcal{C}}\|^{2}+\kappa\Delta^{2}\ll\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{m}}.

Note that Îºğœ…\kappa can be as small as ğ’ªâ€‹(f/n)ğ’ªğ‘“ğ‘›\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{f}}{{n}}\right), hence the above means that, when heterogeneity is limited and with a small enough fraction of adversarial clients, high level of collaborations can be used by each correct client. On the other hand, correct clients need not gain much by collaborating with other clients in highly heterogeneous regimes.

We further make the following assumptions on the loss functions. To conduct an analysis of the effect of collaboration on the generalization performance of correct clients when trying to solveÂ (1), we proceed in two steps. We first evaluate the optimization error that a standard gradient descent algorithm incurs in our setting. Then we bound the generalization gap induced when minimizingÂ (1) and combine the two bounds into our main result in TheoremÂ 1.

3.1 Algorithm & Optimization Error

We focus our analysis on a simple personalized variant of the robust distributed gradient descent algorithm, which is the standard algorithm in the Byzantine-robust FL literature and is shown to achieve tight optimization boundsÂ (Allouah etÂ al.,, 2023). Our variant, presented in AlgorithmÂ 1, essentially corresponds to gradient descent on the function â„’iÎ»superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}, but using a robust estimate Ritsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘¡R_{i}^{t} (iteration 7) of the gradient of â„’ğ’subscriptâ„’ğ’\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{C}}, which cannot be computed exactly due to Byzantine adversaries. This robust estimate is computed using a robust aggregation Fğ¹F, e.g., trimmed mean or median.

On the execution of the algorithm.

Executing AlgorithmÂ 1 in practice implies that each client acts as a local server, and runs an independent federated learning procedure. We further assume that the clients have access to a communication protocol that allows them to broadcast their model to the other clients. This can either be done through the use of the central server or directly through a decentralized communication (i.e., without a server). This algorithm is not communication efficient and we believe that it could be improved in that direction. Nevertheless, it allows us to discuss the information-theoretic aspects of the problem in a simple manner. We first present the optimization error of AlgorithmÂ 1 in LemmaÂ 1 below.

Lemma 1.

Let assumptionsÂ 1,Â 2, andÂ 3 hold. Consider AlgorithmÂ 1 with learning rate Î·=12â€‹Lğœ‚12ğ¿\eta=\frac{1}{2L}, Î»âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ†01\lambda\in[0,1], and assume the aggregation function Fğ¹F to be (f,Îº)ğ‘“ğœ…(f,\kappa)-robust. For any Tâ‰¥1ğ‘‡1T\geq 1, we have:

â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸iT)âˆ’â„’i,âˆ—Î»superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta_{i}^{T})-\mathcal{L}_{i,*}^{\lambda} â‰¤5â€‹Lâ€‹Î»2â€‹Îºâ€‹G2Î¼2+(1âˆ’Î¼2â€‹L)Tâ€‹LÎ¼â€‹â„’0,absent5ğ¿superscriptğœ†2ğœ…superscriptğº2superscriptğœ‡2superscript1ğœ‡2ğ¿ğ‘‡ğ¿ğœ‡subscriptâ„’0\displaystyle\leq\frac{5L\lambda^{2}\kappa G^{2}}{\mu^{2}}+\left(1-\frac{\mu}{2L}\right)^{T}\frac{L}{\mu}\mathcal{L}_{0},

where â„’0:=â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸i0)âˆ’â„’i,âˆ—Î»assignsubscriptâ„’0superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†\mathcal{L}_{0}:=\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta_{i}^{0})-\mathcal{L}_{i,*}^{\lambda} and â„’i,âˆ—Î»â‰”minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸)â‰”superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğœƒÎ˜superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†ğœƒ\mathcal{L}_{i,*}^{\lambda}\coloneqq\min\limits_{\theta\in\Theta}\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta).

Our optimization error bound recovers the classical GD linear rate when Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 (local learning), and achieves an asymptotic error in ğ’ªâ€‹(Îºâ€‹G2)ğ’ªğœ…superscriptğº2\mathcal{O}{(\kappa G^{2})} when Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 (full collaboration), which is provably tight under AssumptionÂ 2Â (Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2022). Interestingly, for Î»âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ†01\lambda\in(0,1), the asymptotic error smoothly interpolates in ğ’ªâ€‹(Î»2â€‹Îºâ€‹G2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ†2ğœ…superscriptğº2\mathcal{O}{(\lambda^{2}\kappa G^{2})}, which is expected as lesser collaboration limits the influence of the adversary on the optimization error.

3.2 Generalization Gap & Effect of Collaboration

Although the presence of adversarial clients impairs the optimization process, one expects a generalization benefit from collaboration if data distributions are similar enough. We formalize this intuition by bounding the generalization gap, of the personalized learning problemÂ (2). We first bound the generalization gap on the interpolated loss â„’iÎ»superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda} using a result adapted fromÂ (Blitzer etÂ al.,, 2007).

Lemma 2.

Let AssumptionÂ 4 hold. For any Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0, Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta and Î»âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ†01\lambda\in[0,1], we have with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta (over the choice of samples) that

|â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸)âˆ’â„›iÎ»â€‹(Î¸)|â‰¤2â€‹Î²â€‹((1âˆ’Î»+Î»nâˆ’f)2m+Î»2mâ€‹(nâˆ’f)),superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘–ğœ†ğœƒ2ğ›½superscript1ğœ†ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘“2ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ†2ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘“|\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta)-\mathcal{R}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta)|\leq 2\beta\sqrt{\left(\frac{\left(1-\lambda+\frac{\lambda}{n-f}\right)^{2}}{m}+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{m(n-f)}\right)},

where â„›iÎ»â€‹(Î¸)â‰”ğ”¼â€‹[â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸)],âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜formulae-sequenceâ‰”superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘–ğœ†ğœƒğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†ğœƒfor-allğœƒÎ˜\mathcal{R}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}{[\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta)]},\forall\theta\in\Theta, and Î²â‰”Pdimâ€‹(â„‹)â€‹logâ¡(eâ€‹mPdimâ€‹(â„‹))+logâ¡(1/Î´)â‰”ğ›½Pdimâ„‹ğ‘’ğ‘šPdimâ„‹1ğ›¿\beta\coloneqq\sqrt{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}\log\left(\frac{em}{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}}\right)}+\sqrt{\log(1/\delta)}.

When specializing the result of LemmaÂ 2 to Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 and Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1, we recover the standard generalization gaps ğ’ªâ€‹(Pdimâ€‹(â„‹)/m)ğ’ªPdimâ„‹ğ‘š\mathcal{O}{\left(\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}}}{{m}}}\right)} and ğ’ªâ€‹(Pdimâ€‹(â„‹)/mâ€‹(nâˆ’f))ğ’ªPdimâ„‹ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘“\mathcal{O}{\left(\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}}}{{m(n-f)}}}\right)} for local learning and federated learning (with correct clients only), respectively. However, in addition to the generalization gap bounded in LemmaÂ 2, we need to bound the gap between the interpolated riskÂ (3) and the original local riskÂ (1). In fact, these two objectives are statistically different when there is data heterogeneity among clients since the interpolated riskÂ (3) involves the average of local loss functions. To quantify this difference, we leverage tools from domain adaptation theoryÂ (Ben-David etÂ al.,, 2010) and consider a function Î¦Î¦\Phi measuring the discrepancy between two statistical distributions. Formally, we require for every iâˆˆğ’ğ‘–ğ’i\in\mathcal{C},

|â„›iâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ’â„›ğ’â€‹(Î¸)|â‰¤Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’),âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„›ğ‘–ğœƒsubscriptâ„›ğ’ğœƒÎ¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’for-allğœƒÎ˜|\mathcal{R}_{i}(\theta)-\mathcal{R}_{\mathcal{C}}(\theta)|\leq\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}}),\forall\theta\in\Theta. (7)

For example, for the case of 0-1 loss in binary classification, for any two distributions ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1\mathcal{D}_{1} and ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2\mathcal{D}_{2},Â (Blitzer etÂ al.,, 2007) propose the discrepancy measure to be Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’Ÿ2)=dâ„‹â€‹Î”â€‹â„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’Ÿ2)â‰”2â€‹suphâˆˆâ„‹|â„™ğ’Ÿ1â€‹(Iâ€‹(h))âˆ’â„™ğ’Ÿ2â€‹(Iâ€‹(h))|Î¦subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ‘‘â„‹Î”â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ2â‰”2subscriptsupremumâ„â„‹subscriptâ„™subscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ¼â„subscriptâ„™subscriptğ’Ÿ2ğ¼â„\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2})=d_{\mathcal{H}\Delta\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2})\coloneqq 2\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}|\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}(I(h))-\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}(I(h))|, where Iâ€‹(h)â‰”{xâˆˆğ’³:hâ€‹(x)=1}â‰”ğ¼â„conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’³â„ğ‘¥1I(h)\coloneqq\{x\in\mathcal{X}:h(x)=1\}. For more general losses, we can use hypothesis space-dependent Integral Probability MetricsÂ (Sriperumbudur etÂ al.,, 2009; Bao etÂ al.,, 2023), which we include in SectionÂ B.2. Theorem 1.

Interpretation.

The bound in TheoremÂ 1 features a trade-off between data heterogeneity, sample size, and model complexity. Indeed, we minimize the bound in TheoremÂ 1 and obtain the following closed-form approximation by ignoring constant and logarithmic terms, and assuming that n,Tâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘›ğ‘‡1n,T\gg 1 (see AppendixÂ C for details)

Î»âˆ—â‰ˆÎ [0,1]â€‹(Pdimâ€‹(â„‹)mâˆ’Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’)fnâ€‹G2),superscriptğœ†subscriptÎ 01Pdimâ„‹ğ‘šÎ¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’ğ‘“ğ‘›superscriptğº2\lambda^{*}\approx\Pi_{[0,1]}\left(\frac{\sqrt{\tfrac{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}}{m}}-\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}})}{\tfrac{f}{n}G^{2}}\right), (9)

where Î [0,1]subscriptÎ 01\Pi_{[0,1]} denotes the projection over [0,1]01[0,1]. This expression suggests that the optimal collaboration parameter decreases with data heterogeneity. Indeed, if Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’)>Pdimâ€‹(â„‹)/mÎ¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’Pdimâ„‹ğ‘š\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}})>\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}}}{{m}}}, then Î»âˆ—=0superscriptğœ†0\lambda^{*}=0 and local learning, as expected, is optimal. Otherwise, the optimal collaboration parameter can be non-zero. This validates the fact that correct clients cannot improve their local generalization when their local distributions are too dissimilar compared to the complexity of the hypothesis class and the number of data points each of them has. Furthermore, even if the heterogeneity Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’)Î¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}}) sufficiently small compared to Pdimâ€‹(â„‹)/mPdimâ„‹ğ‘š\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\mathrm{Pdim}{\left(\mathcal{H}\right)}}}{{m}}}, the level of collaboration must be re-evaluated according to fnâ€‹G2ğ‘“ğ‘›superscriptğº2\frac{f}{n}G^{2}; hence depending on both the fraction of adversaries and the dissimilarity of the gradient between correct clients.

3.3 Experimental Validation

Setup.

We empirically investigate the impact of Byzantine adversaries on the generalization performance, in our personalization framework, using the Phishing dataset (Chiew etÂ al.,, 2019) and the MNIST datasetÂ (LeCun and Cortes,, 2010). Other experiments are included in AppendixÂ D. For the different experiments, we use the state-of-the-art defense under data heterogeneity: NNM pre-aggregation (Allouah etÂ al.,, 2023) rule followed by trimmed mean as robust aggregation (Yin etÂ al.,, 2018). We simulate the Byzantine attack with the Sign Flipping attackÂ (Li etÂ al.,, 2020). Throughout the experiments, we fix n=20ğ‘›20n=20, and only vary the local dataset size mğ‘šm, the fraction of Byzantine adversaries fğ‘“f, and the heterogeneity level Î±ğ›¼\alpha which we will explain in the next paragraph. The clients execute AlgorithmÂ 1 for Tğ‘‡T iterations which depends on the dataset being used. FigureÂ 2, as well as the figures in AppendixÂ D, show the average results and error bars for 555 random runs.

To simulate heterogeneity, we use a Dirichlet distribution (Hsu etÂ al.,, 2019) to generate datasets with unbalanced class fractions for each client. The parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha determines the heterogeneity degree (the smaller the bigger the heterogeneity). We subsequently sample the test datasets using the same class distribution as the train datasets for each client, and we evaluate the trained models on these local datasets. We defer the implementation details to AppendixÂ D.

FigureÂ 2, as well as FigureÂ 6 from AppendixÂ D, show the final local test accuracy performance as a function of the degree of collaboration (Î»ğœ†\lambda) for different values of f,mğ‘“ğ‘šf,m and Î±ğ›¼\alpha. These experimental results shed light on the impact of these different factors and allow us to confirm the main insights of our theory.

Full collaboration can be suboptimal.

This can be gleaned from settings where the adversarial fraction is substantial (over 666 adversarial clients, e.g. green and red curves in FigureÂ 2), when the heterogeneity is large (small values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, e.g. blue and orange curves in FigureÂ 6 in AppendixÂ D) and when the local dataset is large enough (e.g. FigureÂ 2(b) and FigureÂ 2(c)). In situations where the adversarial fraction is critical (f=9ğ‘“9f=9, corresponding to red curves in FigureÂ 2 ), robust federated learning completely fails, achieving accuracy scores under 50%percent5050\% on the local test datasets. FigureÂ 5 in AppendixÂ D further illustrates this point, showing that even local learning can be better than state-of-the-art robust Federated Learning in these circumstances.

Fine-tuning the collaboration helps get the best of both worlds.

FigureÂ 2(Bottom) shows that in data scarcity scenarios, for moderate values of the number of adversarial clients (f=3ğ‘“3f=3 or f=6ğ‘“6f=6), using a collaboration degree strictly between 00 and 111 yields better accuracy on the local test dataset. The same effect also appears in FigureÂ 2(Top) for f=3ğ‘“3f=3 and FigureÂ 4 in AppendixÂ D. Additionally, even for extreme adversarial fractions (f=9ğ‘“9f=9 in our experiments), the gain from decreasing the collaboration degree can be substantial compared to simply using Robust Federated Learning methods. This suggests that fine-tuning the collaboration degree can help dampen the detrimental effects of adversarial clients.

4 Conclusion & Future Work

In this paper, we have taken a first step towards understanding how fine-tuning personalization in FL can mitigate the impact of adversarial clients. The results we obtain suggest that the use of personalization can improve the performance of FL algorithms in the presence of adversarial clients, but also that the level of collaboration needs to be chosen carefully. Our theoretical analysis accounts for the necessity to strike a balance between the optimization error, which is impacted by adversarial clients, and the generalization gap, which is likely to benefit from a larger pool of data. We identify the main factors that impact the local performance, namely data heterogeneity, the fraction of adversarial clients, and data scarcity. This work could be extended in several directions. Firstly, as explained in SectionÂ 3, the study of AlgorithmÂ 1 primarily serves our understanding of the robust interpolated optimization problem inÂ (3) from an information-theoretic perspective. However, it may not be efficient enough to cope with high-dimensional learning tasks involving a number of clients. An interesting future direction could be to investigate alternative algorithms with lower communication and computational costs, which would be able to handle these high-dimensional problems. Second, our study focuses on a personalization strategy that interpolates between client loss functions. Although this strategy is simple to interpret and allows us to derive optimization and generalization bounds, it is only one of many possible personalized FL schemes. Another interesting avenue would be to investigate whether the insights we drew from our interpolated problem could be derived in a similar fashion from other personalization frameworks such as regularization, layer specialization, or clustering.

Appendix A Related Work

Personalized federated learning.

As federated learning methods are typically challenged by data heterogeneityÂ (Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2021), many personalization methods have recently been proposed to learn different models tailored for each client. A first category of personalized learning algorithms is based upon local fine-tuningÂ (Fallah etÂ al.,, 2020; Dinh etÂ al.,, 2020), where the goal is to collaboratively find a good global model from which local fine-tuning can result in an improved local performance. A second category of personalized algorithms is based upon regularization between local modelsÂ (Li etÂ al.,, 2021; Kundu etÂ al.,, 2022), i.e., adding a regularization term penalizing a distance between local client models. Another line of research in personalized federated learning considers partial personalization where the parameters are split into globally shared and individual local parameters (Bietti etÂ al.,, 2022; Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2023), this, however, creates the additional challenge of choosing this split. Personalization can also be implemented through clustering methods, where participants selectively collaborate with a smaller subset of clients to limit their exposure to heterogeneity (Ghosh etÂ al.,, 2020; Werner etÂ al.,, 2023; Bao etÂ al.,, 2023). (Mansour etÂ al.,, 2020) proposed and analyzed three different interpolation methods to formalize personalization, including the one we consider in this paper, which they refer to as data interpolation. Although they discuss the generalization properties of this model, they do not address Byzantine robustness.

Personalization for Byzantine robustness. A few works in the personalized learning literature suggest that personalization can improve the robustness to Byzantine participants (Li etÂ al.,, 2021; Kundu etÂ al.,, 2022; Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2023). These works however only present a limited theoretical analysis in the general Byzantine context. For instance, contrary to our work, the theoretical results in (Li etÂ al.,, 2021) only cover linear regression and random Gaussian noise attacks. Moreover, the results of (Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2023) concerning Byzantine robustness make very strong assumptions on the heterogeneity of loss functions, essentially assuming that they share a common minimum, which largely mitigates the effect of Byzantine adversaries on the optimization errorÂ (Allouah etÂ al.,, 2024). Both (Kundu etÂ al.,, 2022; Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2023) only analyze the optimization error and do not study the generalization error, which we showcase as an important part of the trade-off.

B.1 Strong Convexity

A close, but weaker version of strong convexity is the Polyak-Lojasiewicz condition defined below:

Definition 2 (Polyak-Lojasiewicz (PL)).

A function â„’:â„dâ†’â„:â„’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\mathcal{L}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is said to satisfy Polyak-Lojasiewicz with parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu, noted Î¼ğœ‡\mu-PL if âˆ€xâˆˆâ„dfor-allğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}:

â„’â€‹(x)âˆ’infâ„dâ„’â‰¤12â€‹Î¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡â„’â€‹(x)â€–2â„’ğ‘¥subscriptinfimumsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„’12ğœ‡superscriptnormâˆ‡â„’ğ‘¥2\mathcal{L}(x)-\inf_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\mathcal{L}\leq\frac{1}{2\mu}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(x)\|^{2} (10)

If a function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex, it satisfies Î¼ğœ‡\mu-PL condition. Indeed a Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} satisfies:

Î¼2â€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–2+âŸ¨âˆ‡â„’â€‹(y),xâˆ’yâŸ©â‰¤â„’â€‹(x)âˆ’â„’â€‹(y).ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦2âˆ‡â„’ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â„’ğ‘¥â„’ğ‘¦\frac{\mu}{2}\|x-y\|^{2}+\left\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}(y),\,x-y\right\rangle\leq\mathcal{L}(x)-\mathcal{L}(y). (11)

Here, our goal is to reasonably approximate the value of lambda Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} for which the right-hand side ofÂ (24) is minimized. To do so, we first ignore the asymptotically negligible terms. Essentially, we consider that Tğ‘‡T is large enough so that the term (1âˆ’Î¼2â€‹L)Tâ€‹LÎ¼â€‹(â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸i0)âˆ’â„’iÎ»â€‹(Î¸^iÎ»))superscript1ğœ‡2ğ¿ğ‘‡ğ¿ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptsubscript^ğœƒğ‘–ğœ†\left(1-\frac{\mu}{2L}\right)^{T}\frac{L}{\mu}\left(\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\theta_{i}^{0})-\mathcal{L}_{i}^{\lambda}(\widehat{\theta}_{i}^{\lambda})\right) is close enough to zero. In the reminder, we denote by Î¸iâˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i}^{\infty} the output of AlgorithmÂ 1 for Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty. Even after ignoring this term, seeking the optimal value Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} is the solution to a 4th-degree equation, which may not admit a close-form solution in general. To make the computation of an approximate minimizer more tractable, we proceed with the following simplification using the fact that a+bâ‰¤a+bğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\sqrt{a+b}\leq\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b} for any a,bâ‰¥0ğ‘ğ‘0a,b\geq 0:

â„›iâ€‹(Î¸iâˆ)âˆ’â„›iâ€‹(Î¸iâˆ—)â‰¤Î±â€‹Î»2+2â€‹Î»â€‹Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’)+4â€‹1âˆ’(1âˆ’1|ğ’|)â€‹Î»mâ€‹Î²+4â€‹Î»â€‹|ğ’|âˆ’1|ğ’|â€‹mâ€‹Î²,subscriptâ„›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptâ„›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ›¼superscriptğœ†22ğœ†Î¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’4111ğ’ğœ†ğ‘šğ›½4ğœ†ğ’1ğ’ğ‘šğ›½\mathcal{R}_{i}(\theta_{i}^{\infty})-\mathcal{R}_{i}(\theta_{i}^{*})\leq\alpha\lambda^{2}+2\lambda\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}})+4\frac{1-(1-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{C}|})\lambda}{\sqrt{m}}\beta+4\frac{\lambda\sqrt{|\mathcal{C}|-1}}{|\mathcal{C}|\sqrt{m}}\beta, (25)

with Î±:=6â€‹Lâ€‹Îºâ€‹G2Î¼2assignğ›¼6ğ¿ğœ…superscriptğº2superscriptğœ‡2\alpha:=\frac{6L\kappa G^{2}}{\mu^{2}}. Now the right-hand side is a quadratic function of Î»ğœ†\lambda which can be easily minimized. Specifically, the solution of (25) is

Î»âˆ—=2â€‹(1âˆ’1|ğ’|)â€‹Î²Î±â€‹mâˆ’2â€‹|ğ’|âˆ’1|ğ’|â€‹Î±â€‹mâ€‹Î²âˆ’Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’)Î±superscriptğœ†211ğ’ğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘š2ğ’1ğ’ğ›¼ğ‘šğ›½Î¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’ğ›¼\begin{split}\lambda^{*}&=2\left(1-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{C}|}\right)\frac{\beta}{\alpha\sqrt{m}}-2\frac{\sqrt{|\mathcal{C}|-1}}{|\mathcal{C}|\alpha\sqrt{m}}\beta-\frac{\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}})}{\alpha}\end{split} (26)

Assuming |ğ’|ğ’|\mathcal{C}| is large enough, we simplify the above as

Î»âˆ—â‰ˆ2â€‹Î²Î±â€‹mâˆ’Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’)Î±â‰ˆ1Î±â€‹(2â€‹Î²mâˆ’Î¦â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿğ’))superscriptğœ†2ğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘šÎ¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’ğ›¼1ğ›¼2ğ›½ğ‘šÎ¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ’\begin{split}\lambda^{*}&\approx\frac{2\beta}{\alpha\sqrt{m}}-\frac{\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}})}{\alpha}\\ &\approx\frac{1}{\alpha}\left(\frac{2\beta}{\sqrt{m}}-\Phi(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{C}})\right)\end{split} (27)

Appendix D Experimental Details

In this section, we give the implementation details of our experiments for each setting and we provide some additional figures. For all the experiments, we run AlgorithmÂ 1 with full gradients for a number Tğ‘‡T of iterations which we change depending on the dataset.
